thread.title: Julio Jones' unselfish approach helps Falcons on field, earns teammates' respect
thread.title_full: Julio Jones' unselfish approach helps Falcons on field, earns teammates' respect

author: USA TODAY Sports
title: Julio Jones' unselfish approach helps Falcons on field, earns teammates' respect
text:
Julio Jones' unselfish approach helps Falcons on field, earns teammates' respect The Falcons' Julio Jones is no diva, and his unselfish attitude helps the team produce. Post to Facebook Julio Jones' unselfish approach helps Falcons on field, earns teammates' respect The Falcons' Julio Jones is no diva, and his unselfish attitude helps the team produce.  //usat.ly/2k4FqNH   Join the Nation's Conversation To   Julio Jones' unselfish approach helps Falcons on field, earns teammates' respect Lindsay H. Jones , USA TODAY Sports 2:19 p.m. ET Feb. 3, 2017 CLOSE x Share USA TODAY Sports' Tom Pelissero breaks down what to look out for from Houston as the New England Patriots and Atlanta Falcons prepare for Super Bowl LI. USA TODAY Sports Falcons WR Julio Jones has long been QB Matt Ryan's (2) favorite target. (Photo: Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports) 
HOUSTON — The next time Atlanta Falcons wide receiver Julio Jones begs his head coach for the ball, it will be the first in their two years together. 
Dan Quinn said he could remember just one instance since coming to the Falcons in 2015 that Jones even approached him about getting the ball more. And even then, it was a suggestion — posed in the form of a question — based on something he was seeing from the defense. 
Jones might be the Falcons’ best player and biggest star, but he’s in no way the team’s diva. 
"None of those things you might associate with a name type player,” Quinn said recently. 
MORE SUPER BOWL COVERAGE 
The closest thing Jones gets to boastful seemed to come Wednesday, when asked directly if he thinks anyone in the NFL could cover him one on one. 
“I do not,” he replied. 
Throughout Super Bowl week, teammates and coaches have described Jones as humble and hard working, detailing the practice habits of a generous teammate who wants others to excel. 
“He’s not a selfish guy at all. He likes for the ball to be spread around so everyone can get their touches — which is smart, because you don’t want to demand the ball all the time — so now you’re drawing everybody to you. You want the ball to be spread out, so that in turn you can get open yourself,” veteran receiver Eric Weems told USA TODAY Sports. 
It’s an attitude that could help the Falcons in Super Bowl LI should the New England Patriots’ game plan be focused on finding a way to try to eliminate Jones. If he isn’t demanding the ball when coverage tells quarterback Matt Ryan to throw it elsewhere, other Falcons can shine. 
“We understand people are going to take me away, because I’m a threat,” Jones said. “But we have so many weapons on the offensive side of the ball. I mean, they see it on film. They're going to do what they can, and they're going to make guys step up and make plays, and then make in-game adjustments. But probably coming out, they might try to take me away.” 
What Jones and the Falcons are hoping to find is that with so much attention on him, other receivers like Mohammed Sanu and Taylor Gabriel, will win their one-on-one battles, or running backs Devonta Freeman and Tevin Coleman will find space. That’s the way Atlanta beat the Denver Broncos earlier this year, when Aqib Talib held Jones to just two catches for 29 yards. 
MORE FALCONS COVERAGE Falcons DT Grady Jarrett hopes to win ring that eluded his dad, Jessie Tuggle 
But the Falcons are also counting on Jones to win the matchup against New England’s top corner, Malcolm Butler, and like their chances even when Jones draws two defenders. In two games against the Seattle Seahawks this year, when he was primarily covered by Pro Bowl corner Richard Sherman, Jones had 13 catches for 206 yards and two touchdowns. 
“He’s a nightmare to game plan for, no doubt about it,” Falcons wide receivers coach Raheem Morris told USA TODAY Sports. 
And Morris would know. He was head coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers when the Falcons drafted Jones in 2011. In two games that year against Morris’ Bucs, with corners Talib and Ronde Barber among the players on Tampa Bay's defense, the rookiehad 10 catches for 191 yards and two touchdowns. 
Now a two-time all-pro and four-time Pro Bowler, Jones only seems to be getting better, leading the NFL in receiving yards per game each of the past two seasons. He returned to practice this week after taking it easy in Georgia after the NFC title game because of a toe injury. He's spent extra time watching how the Patriots have defended opposing No. 1 receiver in hopes of getting a better idea of what might happen Sunday. 
“It takes a team to win a game. I can play really well individually, but I can’t win the game by myself,” Jones said. “It’s a team effort. I’m doing my job. If I’m taking two guys away on that play, I’m doing my job.” 
*** 
Follow Lindsay H. Jones on Twitter @bylindsayhjones 
PHOTOS: Falcons' road to Super Bowl LI Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Week 1: Atlanta stumbled out of the gates with a 31-24 loss to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. The Falcons couldn't keep up with Jameis Winston, who threw for 284 yards and four touchdowns. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Week 2: The Falcons outlasted the Oakland Raiders in a wild one thanks to Taylor Gabriel's 8-yard touchdown catch on a tipped pass. Atlanta's defense held on a fourth-and-2 run to help wrap up the first win of the year. Cary Edmondson, USA TODAY Sports Week 3: The depth of the Falcons' offense began to show in a 45-23 win over the New Orleans Saints. Running back Tevin Coleman scored three touchdowns, while Devonta Freeman had 207 yards from scrimmage. Derick E. Hingle, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Week 4: Julio Jones and Matt Ryan both exploded for record days in Atlanta's 48-33 win over the defending NFC-champion Carolina Panthers. Jones finished with a franchise-record 300 receiving yards on 12 catches, falling just short of the NFL record of 336, while Ryan's 503 passing yards were also a team best. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Week 5: Atlanta handed the defending Super Bowl-champion Denver Broncos their first loss despite a less explosive output from its offense. The Falcons rattled rookie Paxton Lynch, who was making his first start at QB for the Broncos, and relied on a steady output from its running backs to seal the win. Ron Chenoy, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Week 6: Dan Quinn's return to Seattle ended in disappointment as the Falcons fell 26-24 to the Seahawks amid controversy. Richard Sherman appeared to interfere with Julio Jones on a deep fourth-and-10 pass in the final two minutes, but officials did not call a penalty. Joe Nicholson, USA TODAY Sports Week 7: A wild comeback left the Falcons stunned in a 33-30 overtime loss to the San Diego Chargers. Atlanta held at 27-10 lead but couldn't hold on, and Josh Lambo kicked the game-winning field goal in overtime. Dale Zanine, USA TODAY Sports Week 8: A 33-32 last-second win over the Green Bay Packers broke Atlanta out of its two-game slide. Mohamed Sanu's 11-yard touchdown catch in the final minute gave the Falcons the final edge. Brett Davis, USA TODAY Sports Week 9: Atlanta avenged its season-opening loss to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers with a 43-28 triumph in the rematch. Matt Ryan threw for 344 yards and four touchdowns to help the Falcons extend their NFC South lead. Reinhold Matay, USA TODAY Sports Week 10: The Falcons entered their bye week on a sour note after tripping in a 24-15 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles. Ryan Mathews ran for two touchdowns and the Falcons had to settle for three field goals. Eric Hartline, USA TODAY Sports Week 12: Taylor Gabriel emerged as the Falcons' newest weapon in a 38-19 win over the Arizona Cardinals. The diminutive receiver and free agent pickup took two short passes for touchdowns and had four receptions for 75 yards. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Week 13: Eric Berry proved to be a worthy foe for the Falcons, as the Kansas City Chiefs escaped with a 29-28 win. Berry returned one interception and became the first player to return a two-point conversion for a score to seal Kansas City's win. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Week 14: Atlanta's defense got in on the scoring in a 42-14 rout of the Los Angeles Rams. Deion Jones returned an interception for a touchdown, and Vic Beasley forced a Jared Goff fumble that he scooped up for a score. Jayne Kamin-Oncea, USA TODAY Sports Week 15: Devonta Freeman took control in the Falcons' 41-13 win over the San Francisco 49ers. Freeman ran for 139 rushing yards and three touchdowns in the romp. Dale Zanine, USA TODAY Sports Week 16: A balanced offensive effort helped the Falcons ease past the Carolina Panthers in a 33-16 win. Atlanta intercepted Cam Newton twice and held him to 198 yards. Bob Donnan, USA TODAY Sports Week 17: The Falcons put the finishing touches on their NFC South title with a 38-32 win over the New Orleans Saints. Atlanta clinched the No. 2 seed in the NFC and a first-round bye with the win. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Divisional round: The Falcons didn't leave their playoff fate to another late call, as they rolled past the Seattle Seahawks for a 36-20 win. Matt Ryan threw for 338 yards and three touchdowns, while the defense threw off Russell Wilson and Seattle's attack. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NFC Championship Game: Atlanta sealed just its second-ever trip to the Super Bowl with a 44-21 thrashing of the Green Bay Packers. The Falcons' red-hot offense racked up 493 yards, and Aaron Rodgers was held in check after a wild late-season run. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay
